description: From Ancient Greek ἀναφορά (anaphorá, “a carrying back”), from ἀνά (aná, “up”) + φέρω (phérō, “I carry”).

nouns.description: anaphora (countable and uncountable, plural anaphoras or anaphors or anaphora)

entries.meaning: (rhetoric) The repetition of a phrase at the beginning of phrases, sentences, or verses, used for emphasis.
examples: They didn't speak. They didn't stand. They didn't even look up when I came in.

entries.meaning: (linguistics) An expression that can refer to virtually any referent, the specific referent being defined by context.
(linguistics) An expression that refers to a preceding expression.
(Christianity) The most solemn part of the Divine Liturgy or the Mass during which the offerings of bread and wine are consecrated as body and blood of Christ.
